Posts.Content: janejetson wrote: Tomorrow morning I'm going in to have a biopsy of my biopsy. Actually it a biopsy of a thickened area of redness and swelling that developed after a biopsy I had in July (12 weeks ago.) The original biopsy was a benign lymph node but 2 or 3 inches away from the location, the stereotactic machine hit a blood vessel, this swelling in that area began that turned red and hardened and dimpled. After antibiotics for 10 days it dulled the red and the gardness got softer, but the edema is still there. I feel my surgeon is trust worthy and kknowledgeable, but I seem to have him stumped. After an ultrasound which showed boyhing abnormal, he has decided to biopsy the area to as he says "rule out inflamatory cancer and look for a bacterial infection." He says that if this comes back as ibc then its the weirdest case of cancer he has ever seen, and he has had a long career. Anyone ever deal with anything similar? Trying not to go crazy with worry. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: biopsy of thickened skin... janejetson janejetson

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2013 07:19AM janejetson wrote: thanks for the replies. I dont get results until Tuesday or Wednesday. A friend of mine was the surgical nurse for my biopsy and said that when she spoke to the doctor afterward he said that it was very superficial and he is thinking its just inflamation. It bothers me because during my original biopsy they hit a blood vessel it was really painful, but my current swelling is in the area where I had the blood vessel pain. Id assume the swelling 12 weeks post surgery is related, I didnt think you can trigger IBC, and I had no redness or swelling prior to that incident but the doctor mentions biopsy for IBC and rational thought goes out the window. I already have a hard time trusting doctors and I seem to have this one stumped (aside from his not thinking this is bad statement.) Now of course the swelling and pain is worse, but I have a new biopsy site. Ah, stress! Thanks for reading and responding to my rants, It does help to get responses.

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2013 02:55PM janejetson wrote: in a mixup of things today IIwas given a pathology report of a "anaerobic and aerobic culture" from my biopsy, so i assume they are still waiting for the skin pathology a week later?! I was supposed to receive results tuesday and its now friday and my doctor is on vacation. Awesome! Im so confused and I still have no answers. :(
Posts.Title: biopsy of thickened skin... janejetson janejetson

Posts.Content: janejetson wrote: I've chatted with a few helpful people from this site before who have really helped with concerns and information. It has been now 5 months since my original lymph node biopsy (negative) which triggered redness, swelling and peau d'orange on the opposite side of the same breast. That caused my surgeon to do another biopsy, this time a surgical skin biopsy on the edge of my nipple where the swelling was causing my skin to thicken. That biopsy too was negative for cancer, positive for a fibroid tumor. Of course then all doctors (I had seen 2, breast surgeon and obgyn) said "ah yes the swelling is the fault of the fibroid tumor, mystery solved!" And that was that. I came across an article that said that one skin biopsy was not effective in diagnosing IBC, of course this uos my anxiety because while my redness is gone I still have permanant thickened skin and obvious hair follicles In that area of my breast. While I have been under the impression of probable lymphedema, the doctors have adamantly disagreed or basicly shrugged. There are no lymph specialists anywhere near me. Not that I can afford it as all of these biopsies have pushed me into debt already, and such a mental toll should I be seeking a third opinion? My obgyn really tried to explain the fibroid tumor to me but I dont get why this would present this swelling. My surgeon explains that "its somewhere in there blocking things up." Does anyone have any thoughts on this? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: 5 months post biopsy IBC / other worries janejetson janejetson

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2013 07:44AM janejetson wrote: Thanks for the reply, yes the redness and swelling its all in the lower part. It seems to me that it would no longer be so red, and im pretty sure its not infection because im just finishing up a round of antibiotics now for something not related. I really hate that my surgeon isnt in until monday... I dont know if my gp could help.
Posts.Title: biopsy healing time janejetson janejetson

Posts.Content: janejetson wrote: So today is 6 weeks since my stereotactic biopsy which resulted in a benign lymph node. During this procedure they hit a blood vessel twice. Needless to say this resulted in bruising and a rather large hematoma. I followed up with the surgeon last Tuesday which was almost 5 weeks post opp and the first thing he noticed was the redness of my breast but proceeded to tell me that the cording and dimples and light pain I'm experiencing is just the natural healing process. What concerns me is that while the biopsy incision was in the upper outter area, after surgery I was bruised also in the lower inner area near my nipple. Now that area is where the redness, tingling, and swelling is occurring. My skin is thick there and dimpled. I find it slightly warm at times, and of course with all that's gone on I'm paranoid about IBC. The doctor did tell me that because of the blood vessel trauma the complete healing could take months, and the tingling pains I feel are probably nerves. Also this thick red area hasn't gotten any worse in the past few weeks it just hasn't gotten better. I have rather large breasts and the part that stays swollen is the part that seems to be the lowest. Has anyone experienced this? Does anyone know if healing could mimic the signs of bc? I'm in such a bad financial situation I just cant afford to run off for a second opinion if its just my anxiety and all I need is time. Any input is appreciated. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: biopsy healing time janejetson janejetson

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2013 08:54PM janejetson wrote: I wouldn't say you are over reacting. The place I went to really put up a fight about doing a mammogram because I'm 30... I went in on doctor's orders for a screening baseline because I have lots of lumps and my doctor thought a baseline comparison would be a good idea, turns out that's how they found the lump I had biopsied last week (still awaiting results.) If there is something about it that still bothers you, try your best to get a second opinion or see a specialist until you get an answer.
Posts.Title: Should I ask for a referral? MummyK MummyK

Posts.Content: janejetson wrote: I am so tired of dealing with this. Maybe someone else has experienced something similar? I have had a surgical breast biopsy years ago that came back benign. However I recently found a little hard lump in the other breast. I visited the same surgeon as the previous time, he referred me for a mammogram and ultrasound and both showed nothing. However my lump cannot be felt laying down only sitting up, so my doctor made me question the ultrasound results when he called the next day and asked me if she did the ultrasound in the right area... he then told me to follow up in 3 months. I felt uneasy, so I decided to have my film transferred and seek a second opinion from another surgeon. This surgeon did an ultrasound himself in the office while sitting up, he saw something tiny and decided to do a biopsy there guided by the ultrasound. (I Am not sure what the correct term is, it was a device with a needle and made snapping sounds). He marked the area with a marker and had a difficult time pin pointing it again after numbing me. After he was done he said it was very tiny and looked mostly like fatty tissue and I probably wouldnt even feel it again. This was two days ago, I'm sore, and my annoying little pea sized knot is still there. Is it possible that he biopsied the wrong area? I wonder now if I am being dilegent or crazy Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Possible biopsy of wrong area? janejetson ready2bedone

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2017 09:00PM janejetson wrote: Went back for follow up today, biopsy was benign and doctor felt lump and agreed that it was not what he biopsied (although he did biopsy something he saw on ultrasound). He said that he did ultrasound this area and nothing alarming came up. He wants me to monitor the area for a while and let him know if it changes, after commenting that "it feels like a bb". That's it... after two surgeons and ultrasounds I don't feel like I have any other options. Apparently I have to live with this and monitor it. Has anyone had a similar experience? I'm just at a loss
